repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Economic
            Recovery and Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credits;
            Congo, Republic of - Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            and Economic Recovery Credits

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings of the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) generally concur with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings, except in
            the following instances: ratings for the Assessment of the
            Economic Recovery Credit Project are as follows: outcome
            (ICR highly satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory); bank
            performance (ICR satisfactory, PPAR moderately
            unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR highly
            satisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory). Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower and bank performance (ICR
            unsatisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory).Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); bank performance (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR
            satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Ratings for the
            Assessment of the Economic Recovery Credit Project are as
            follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory);
            borrower and bank performance (ICR moderately
            unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Some lessons learned
            included:  deep reforms changing the patterns of governance
            and public sector management require adequate preparation,
            including political economy assessment, consensus building
            effort and wide political and social ownership. In the
            absence of such thorough preparation, the likelihood of
            success is low, irrespective of potentially huge long-run
            gains for the country and society. In the post-conflict
            environment, a development policy operation (DPO) instrument
            can be effective if the reform program is well calibrated to
            a context of weak technical capacity and multiple
            priorities. In both countries, and for each operation,
            ownership of reforms was permanently elusive, and was only
            assured fleetingly by the lure of arrears clearance or debt
            relief. Ownership of reforms by respective governments
            followed a pattern of temporary commitment to reforms for
            immediate returns. Incentives to governments, leadership and
            ground conditions lacked for a successful pursuit of the
            ambitious reform agenda in both counties.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo - Post-Conflict Economic
            Rehabilitation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; Borrower performance is satisfactory. A key
            lesson is that a small but timely and well designed
            operation can make a significant contribution to
            consolidating peace, reviving the economy and helping a
            post-conflict country get away from the conflict trap. A
            second lesson is the importance of receiving strong signals
            of Government commitment to reform. In this case, commitment
            was shown by reform efforts launched by Government, with its
            own resources, prior to credit approval. A third lesson is
            that parallel implementation of other mutually reinforcing
            lending operations, notably those providing technical
            assistance, can improve the chances of success. In
            post-conflict countries, a comprehensive, not a partial,
            approach seems more likely to yield quick and positive
            results. A fourth lesson is that for a post-conflict country
            like the Congo, privatization goals should not be too
            ambitious. Efforts to privatize the water and electricity
            utilities, and the railways, were less successful than
            expected because potential investors viewed the risk of
            undertaking large investment as too high A fifth lesson is
            that for a post-conflict country with limited implementation
            capacity, the design of the project should be kept as simple
            as possible. Although this project had only two main
            components, the number of its sub-components (at least six)
            was rather high.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Post-Conflict Economic
            Rehabilitation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post-Conflict Economic
            Rehabilitation Credit (Post-Conflict ERC) is an integral
            part of the World Bank's Transitional Support Strategy
            (TSS) (report no. 21328) to assist the Republic of Congo in
            the transition from war to sustainable peace, in the context
            of the Government's 2000-2002 Interim Post-Conflict
            Program. It is the first operation of the TSS that supports
            implementation of 1) key structural reforms; and 2) improved
            governance and better transparency in managing the
            country's natural wealth and public funds. These
            reforms are needed to stabilize and bring about the economic
            rehabilitation that will pave the way for broad-based
            poverty reduction, and a higher and sustained growth path in
            the years ahead, after three decades of centrally planned
            economic management and almost a decade of war. Proceeds of
            the Credit will provide critical funds needed to assist the
            Republic of Congo with foreign exchange cash immediately
            after arrears to the Bank have been paid. The Credit will be
            disbursed in a single tranche, and implemented in parallel
            with the Transparency and Governance Capacity Building
            Project (see pid10370).
